purpose.answer: My purpose is to help you make sense of your spending, provide financial insights, and guide you towards your goals, all while keeping your data completely private on your device.

sip.answer: A Systematic Investment Plan (SIP) is a way to invest a fixed amount of money in mutual funds at regular intervals. It helps in rupee cost averaging and disciplined investing.

ppf.answer: Public Provident Fund (PPF) is a long-term savings scheme backed by the Indian government. It offers a fixed, tax-free return and is a safe investment option.

fd.answer: A Fixed Deposit (FD) is a financial instrument provided by banks which provides investors with a higher rate of interest than a regular savings account, until the given maturity date.

emergency_fund.answer: An emergency fund is money set aside to cover unexpected financial surprises, like a job loss or medical emergency. It's recommended to have 3-6 months of living expenses saved.

credit_score.answer: A credit score (like CIBIL) is a 3-digit number that represents your creditworthiness. A higher score makes it easier to get loans and credit cards at better interest rates.

debt_snowball.answer: The debt snowball method is a debt-reduction strategy where you pay off debts from smallest to largest, regardless of interest rate. The psychological win of clearing a debt provides momentum.

debt_avalanche.answer: The debt avalanche method is a debt-reduction strategy where you pay off debts with the highest interest rates first. This method saves you the most money in interest over time.

mutual_fund.answer: A mutual fund is a pool of money collected from many investors to invest in stocks, bonds, or other assets. They are managed by professional fund managers.

nps.answer: The National Pension System (NPS) is a voluntary retirement savings scheme that allows subscribers to make defined contributions towards planned retirement.

elss.answer: Equity Linked Savings Scheme (ELSS) is a type of mutual fund that helps you save taxes under Section 80C and also provides an opportunity for long-term capital appreciation.

etf.answer: An Exchange-Traded Fund (ETF) is a type of investment fund and exchange-traded product. They are traded on stock exchanges, much like stocks.

index_fund.answer: An index fund is a type of mutual fund or ETF with a portfolio constructed to match or track the components of a financial market index, such as the NIFTY 50. It offers broad market exposure and typically has low fees.

tax.answer: In India, income tax is levied on individuals based on their income slabs. You can save tax through various deductions under sections like 80C (PPF, ELSS, etc.), 80D (health insurance), and HRA (House Rent Allowance).

inflation.answer: Inflation is the rate at which the general level of prices for goods and services is rising, and subsequently, purchasing power is falling. For example, if inflation is 5%, a ₹100 item will cost ₹105 next year. It's important to invest your money to get returns that are higher than the inflation rate.

compounding.answer: Compounding is the process where your investment's earnings, from either capital gains or interest, earn their own earnings. It's like a snowball effect for your money. The earlier you start investing, the more powerful compounding becomes.

asset_allocation.answer: Asset allocation is the strategy of dividing your investment portfolio among different asset categories, such as stocks, bonds, and cash. The goal is to balance risk and reward by diversifying your investments.

diversification.answer: Diversification means 'not putting all your eggs in one basket.' It's a risk management strategy that mixes a wide variety of investments within a portfolio. A diversified portfolio contains a mix of distinct asset types and investment vehicles in an attempt at limiting exposure to any single asset or risk.

stock_market.answer: The stock market is where investors buy and sell shares of publicly traded companies. In India, the two main stock exchanges are the National Stock Exchange (NSE) and the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE).

insurance.answer: Insurance is a contract (policy) in which an individual receives financial protection or reimbursement against losses from an insurance company. Health insurance covers medical expenses, while life insurance provides a payout to beneficiaries upon the insured's death. Both are crucial for financial security.

50_30_20_rule.answer: The 50/30/20 rule is a simple budgeting guideline. It suggests you should spend 50% of your after-tax income on needs (rent, bills), 30% on wants (entertainment, dining out), and 20% on savings and debt repayment.

edit_transaction.answer: To edit a transaction, go to the 'Home' or 'Transactions' screen and simply tap on the transaction you wish to change. The edit screen will pop up.

delete_transaction.answer: To delete a transaction, go to the 'Home' or 'Transactions' screen. Long-press on a transaction to enter bulk-edit mode, select the ones you want to delete, and tap the trash icon.

link_transaction.answer: When you add or edit a transaction, you'll see a 'Link to Goal' dropdown. You can select any of your active goals from there to link the expense.

set_goal.answer: Go to the 'Goals' screen, select the 'Goals' tab, and tap the floating plus button to add a new goal. You'll be able to set a title, target amount, and an optional deadline.

export_csv.answer: You can export all your transaction data to a CSV file from the 'Settings' page under the Data Management section. You can also export from the 'Transactions' screen.

import_csv.answer: You can import transactions from a CSV file. Go to 'Settings', then 'Data Management', and tap 'Import Data from CSV'. Follow the on-screen instructions for the correct file format.

search.answer: Tap the search icon in the top-right corner of the app to search for transactions, goals, and budgets all at once.

delete_data.answer: Be careful! You can delete all your app data from the 'Settings' page. This action cannot be undone.

change_theme.answer: You can switch between light and dark themes in the 'Settings' page under the 'Appearance' section.

manage_categories.answer: Go to 'Settings' > 'Personalization' > 'Manage Categories'. There you can add new custom categories or delete ones you've created (as long as they are not used by any transactions).

recurring_transactions.answer: Recurring transactions are for automatic payments like rent, subscriptions, or bills. You can set them up in the 'Transactions' screen under the 'Recurring' tab. The app will automatically add them on their due dates.

challenges.answer: Challenges are fun tasks to help you build better spending habits. You can find and start them on the 'Goals' screen under the 'Challenges' tab. Completing them unlocks achievement badges!

streak.answer: The streak counter on the Home screen shows how many consecutive days you have logged at least one transaction. It's a great way to stay motivated and consistent with tracking!

average_mood.answer: The Average Mood on the Home screen is calculated based on all the transactions within the selected time period (Day, Week, Month, or Year). It gives you a quick glance at how you've been feeling about your spending.

help.answer:
I can do a few things:
- Analyze your spending for a day, week, or month.
- Compare your spending between periods.
- Find your biggest spending category.
- Offer saving tips.
- Explain financial topics like SIPs or credit scores.
- Calculate loan EMIs or SIP returns.
- Answer questions about how to use the app.

sentimint.answer: Sentimint is your personal finance tracker. It helps you understand the emotions behind your spending to build healthier financial habits. All your financial data always stays private on your device.

general: Track your spending for a month to see where your money goes.
Create a budget and stick to it. The 50/30/20 rule is a great start (50% Needs, 30% Wants, 20% Savings).
Automate your savings. Set up a recurring transfer to your savings account right after you get paid.
Review your subscriptions. Cancel any you don't use regularly.
Try the '30-day rule' for non-essential purchases. If you still want it after 30 days, consider buying it.
Plan your meals for the week to avoid impulsive food orders and reduce grocery waste.
Unsubscribe from marketing emails to reduce the temptation of sales and promotions.
